Tables I-II report the value of the indicators for all the considered scenarios. Independently on the value of <math alttext="[\lambda]" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1a">
    <mrow id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.2" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.1.cmml">

      <mo id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.2.2" stretchy="false" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.1.1.cmml">]</mo>
    </mrow>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1b">

        <ci id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
      </apply>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1c">[\lambda]</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1d">[ italic_λ ]</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math> (in this nonetheless constant across agents), the worst-case conservative law obtained by solving Eq. (

  <mo id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.2.2" stretchy="false" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.1.1.cmml">]</mo>
</mrow>

]<annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1b">

<apply id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.2">

  <ci id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
</apply>
<csymbol cd="latexml" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.2.2.1">delimited-[]</csymbol>
delimited-[]<ci id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
𝜆<annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1c">[\lambda]</annotation>
[\lambda]<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1d">[ italic_λ ]</annotation>
[ italic_λ ] (in this nonetheless constant across agents), the worst-case conservative law obtained by solving Eq. (13) is the one generally resulting in the most widespread diffusion of a positive inclination. This generally comes at the price of an increased policy cost. From this perspective, the policies with adapting weights tend to outperform the “brute-force” approximation performed in Eq. (10). This confirms the capability of the latter policy to better adapt to changes in individual inclinations (despite the approximation performed in constructing the weights) and, hence, allow policymakers to save money.

Both Tables I-II show a general tendency of costs to increase when more agents tend to be receptive to the policy, while inherently negatively biased. As one would have guessed intuitively, containing investments in such a scenario might be counterproductive. Meanwhile, comparing the results in these tables, it can be noticed that all policies tend to be closer in performance and cost for a higher <math alttext="\lambda" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1a">
    <mi id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1b">
      <ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math>, showcasing the impact that different degrees in social connection can have on the final policy outcome and cost-benefit trade-off. At the same time, these results do not show any specific drop in performance, validating the use of the “simple” estimate Eq. (
<semantics id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1a">
  <mi id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
  <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1b">
    <ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
  </annotation-xml>
  <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
  <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
</semantics>
<mi id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
λ<annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1b">
  <ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
</annotation-xml>
<ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
𝜆<annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
\lambda<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
italic_λ, showcasing the impact that different degrees in social connection can have on the final policy outcome and cost-benefit trade-off. At the same time, these results do not show any specific drop in performance, validating the use of the “simple” estimate Eq. (20) to reconstruct the (hidden) state, at least in this relatively simple example.

𝜆<annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1c">[\lambda]</annotation>
[\lambda]<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p1.1.m1.1d">[ italic_λ ]</annotation>
[ italic_λ ] (in this nonetheless constant across agents), the worst-case conservative law obtained by solving Eq. (13) is the one generally resulting in the most widespread diffusion of a positive inclination. This generally comes at the price of an increased policy cost. From this perspective, the policies with adapting weights tend to outperform the “brute-force” approximation performed in Eq. (10). This confirms the capability of the latter policy to better adapt to changes in individual inclinations (despite the approximation performed in constructing the weights) and, hence, allow policymakers to save money.

Both Tables I-II show a general tendency of costs to increase when more agents tend to be receptive to the policy, while inherently negatively biased. As one would have guessed intuitively, containing investments in such a scenario might be counterproductive. Meanwhile, comparing the results in these tables, it can be noticed that all policies tend to be closer in performance and cost for a higher <math alttext="\lambda" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1a">
    <mi id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1b">
      <ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math>, showcasing the impact that different degrees in social connection can have on the final policy outcome and cost-benefit trade-off. At the same time, these results do not show any specific drop in performance, validating the use of the “simple” estimate Eq. (
<semantics id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1a">
  <mi id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>

  </annotation-xml>

  <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
</semantics>
<mi id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
λ<annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1b">
  <ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
</annotation-xml>
<ci id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
𝜆<annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
\lambda<annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS1.p2.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
italic_λ, showcasing the impact that different degrees in social connection can have on the final policy outcome and cost-benefit trade-off. At the same time, these results do not show any specific drop in performance, validating the use of the “simple” estimate Eq. (20) to reconstruct the (hidden) state, at least in this relatively simple example.

Case 1 96.55 % 87.59 % 5.37 3.62
Case 2 93.79 % 80.17 % 8.83 6.51
Case 3 95.51 % 88.62 % 5.40 3.74
Case 4 91.55 % 72.41 % 13.18 9.63
references:
When considering the impact of external disturbances, we evaluate the same performance criteria as before focusing only on the worst-case policy designed via the mean inclination estimate (E-WC) and the one obtained with such estimate and time-varying weights. The attained performance indicators are reported in Tables III-IV for both the conditions on <math alttext="\lambda" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1a">
    <mi id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1b">
      <ci id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math>, showing that the trends evidenced in the absence of noise are confirmed when (unpredictable) external disturbances impact individual inclinations. At the same time, at least in our example, this shows that the estimate for the mean inclinations can represent an asset in the absence of direct insight into individual beliefs (which are anyway unrealistic in practice).

TABLE IV: Noisy case: indicators for <math alttext="\lambda=0.75" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.T4.2.m1.1">

references:
When considering the impact of external disturbances, we evaluate the same performance criteria as before focusing only on the worst-case policy designed via the mean inclination estimate (E-WC) and the one obtained with such estimate and time-varying weights. The attained performance indicators are reported in Tables III-IV for both the conditions on <math alttext="\lambda" class="ltx_Math" display="inline" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1">
  <semantics id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1a">
    <mi id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1" xref="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml">λ</mi>
    <annotation-xml encoding="MathML-Content" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1b">
      <ci id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1.cmml" xref="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1.1">𝜆</ci>
    </annotation-xml>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1c">\lambda</annotation>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-llamapun" id="S4.SS2.p1.1.m1.1d">italic_λ</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math>, showing that the trends evidenced in the absence of noise are confirmed when (unpredictable) external disturbances impact individual inclinations. At the same time, at least in our example, this shows that the estimate for the mean inclinations can represent an asset in the absence of direct insight into individual beliefs (which are anyway unrealistic in practice).
